Nov 29, 2016

An Open Letter to ’14 TCU Fans About ’16 Ohio State

The errors of the past shouldn’t predict errors of the future.

With Ohio State entering the final week of the College Football Playoff rankings at No. 2, despite not even leading its division or having a spot in its conference’s championship game this weekend, an old discussion has once again begun to rear its ugly head.

The 2014 season is a bittersweet subject for TCU fans and rightfully so. You could make a reasonable argument that it was TCU’s most complete team ever (or at least right there with the 2010 Rose Bowl squad). But it was also a team that famously dropped from No. 3 to No. 6 and out of the playoff rankings after whooping Iowa State, 55–3.

Most fans of TCU and college football fans alike attribute the Frogs’ improbable last-second drop to Ohio State’s 59-point thrashing of Wisconsin in the Big Ten Championship and/or the committee’s sudden affinity for a “13th data point,” a made-up term to give the Buckeyes credit for winning a conference championship game, which TCU didn’t have.

“What gives?” a TCU fan might say in 2016. “Where’s Ohio State’s 13th data point this season? How are you going to put them in front of Penn State, which can still actually win the conference and already beat the Buckeyes earlier in the year?”

Though the playoff committee would likely never admit it, the problem with 2014 wasn’t an Ohio State problem, a TCU problem, a Big 12 problem or even a conference championship problem. It was a Florida State problem.

In all honesty, 2014 Florida State should not have been a playoff team. If we’re truly going by the “four best teams” argument, which the committee has suddenly full-on adopted into its ever-changing vocabulary, the Seminoles didn’t even come close. They slept-walk through a fairly easy schedule, pulling out miraculous comeback after miraculous comeback against lesser competition, en route to a second-straight undefeated season.

But anybody who watched Florida State that season knew they weren’t actually very good. It was obvious.

When the committee had to pick the four teams “worthy” of being in the playoff though, Florida State had to be in there, right or wrong. They were the reigning champs, and they hadn’t lost a game in more than two years.

Even if they weren’t actually one of the four best teams.

So when No. 2 Oregon tore through the Seminoles en route to a 59–20 blowout win in the Rose Bowl, it didn’t surprise anyone. It was simply confirmation that this “playoff team” in Florida State was a sham and didn’t really deserve to be on the same field as the Ducks.

Meanwhile, No. 6 TCU had just finished picking the final bits of flesh off №8 Ole Miss in that memorable 42–3 Peach Bowl obliteration.

I still maintain that ’14 TCU team was one of, if not the best team in college football that year, but they never got a chance to prove it. Not because of their strength of schedule. Not because of 61–58. Not even because of Ohio State. But because Florida State truly lucked their way into an undefeated season.

So keep that in mind, bitter Frog fans. I know it hurts. Trust me, I do. I felt that pain right there with you. But Ohio State is almost a guarantee to make the playoff once again, and honestly, they should be, because, as they were in 2014, they’re one of the four best teams.

It’s as obvious as Florida State’s incompetence was then. If you want something to still be angry at, direct that frustration toward college football’s latest con man of a team.

We don’t want to get in the business of leaving out teams that deserve to be in the playoff based on “prior criteria” because, frankly, every year is different. And just because your deserving team got left out doesn’t mean another deserving team should too. The committee leaving out ‘16 Ohio State won’t put ‘14 TCU in, or change the fact that they both deserve[d] to compete for a championship.

And if the Buckeyes somehow end up proving they don’t deserve to be there? Well, we both know who’ll be first in line to let the committee know just how stupid their mistake was for the second year in three tries.
